;7 月份中国服务业活动扩张速度略快，主要得益于周四的一项私营部门商业调查显示，夏季旅游旺季的业务增长，部分抵消了制造业疲软的拖累。

;

;财新/标普全球服务业采购经理人指数（PMI）升至54.1从 6 月的 53.9 上升到 7 月，标志着整个服务业的商业活动连续第七个月扩张。 50 点的分界线区分了活动的扩张和收缩。

;

;该数据与周一的官方调查形成鲜明对比，后者显示服务业活动继续疲软。分析师表示，接受调查的公司构成和方法论的不同可能是造成这种差异的原因。

;

;去年年底突然取消严格的冠状病毒限制措施后，世界第二大经济体在第一季度实现了强劲反弹，但随着国内外需求减弱，近几个月复苏迅速消退。

;

;近几周当局推出了一系列政策措施来支持疲软的复苏，但细节很少，投资者正在期待

;

;“政策方面，保就业、稳预期、增加居民收入仍是首要任务。”财新智库高级经济学家王哲表示。

;<私人调查显示，各公司表示，经营状况的改善、客户数量的增加和新产品的发布推动了第三季度初的销售额。新业务分项指数较6月份有所回升，但仍低于系列平均水平。

;

;分析师表示，夏季旅游可能有助于相关消费，尽管一些大件商品的销售仍然不温不火，使7月份的情况有所改善。零售额喜忧参半。

;

;“入夏以来，顾客数量比去年同期增长了60%至70%。”杭州一家民宿服务的吴姓接待员说。

;

;更好的销售鼓励企业以自 3 月份以来最快的速度扩大薪资数量。

;

;然而，企业的积极情绪水平降至八个月低点并下降低于该系列的长期趋势。

;

;费用的持续增长和需求的改善导致公司的价格进一步上涨，尽管一些人表示竞争的市场压力限制了他们的定价能力。

;

;财新/标准普尔综合 PMI（包括制造业和服务业活动）从 6 月份的 52.5 降至 51.9，连续第七个月扩张。然而，增速是1月份以来的最低水平。

;

;“服务业和制造业复苏不平衡是一个突出问题，”经济学家王说。

;中国通讯应用程序微信不同意澳大利亚议会报告中的描述方式，包括与 TikTok 一起被列为具有“独特的国家安全风险”，但表示将继续与堪培拉就其担忧进行合作。

;

;周二，澳大利亚对通过社交媒体进行的外国干涉进行了调查其调查结果，其中包括禁止在政府设备上使用微信的建议。

;

;4 月份，澳大利亚与其包括美国和英国在内的西方盟友一致，禁止在政府设备上使用 TikTok。

;

;“我们正在详细审查委员会的报告和建议。正如我们向参议院委员会传达的那样，微信致力于保护用户隐私，并为用户提供一个安全可靠、多样化的平台，用于与朋友、家人和企业进行交流。”微信在《亚洲周刊》的一份声明中表示。 p>;

;澳大利亚人看到了与中国紧密联系的好处，但希望禁止中国应用程序：民意调查

;

;微信上周通过书面答复告诉调查委员会，北京从未要求其监视用户。

;

;调查报告还建议澳大利亚所有主要社交媒体平台保持在该国的存在，并考虑效仿美国，将 TikTok Australia 与其中国母公司字节跳动分开（如果华盛顿方面取得成功）

;

;它批评微信没有出席调查听证会，TikTok没有提供委员会寻求的证人，但赞扬了谷歌和Meta等西方国家的平台，这些平台“至少承认了”民主制度固有的制衡的根本重要性”。

;

;该报告概述了与中国相关的应用程序的危险，这些应用程序可能会“与中国情报机构秘密合作”，尽管它表示“同样严重的风险是西方社交媒体公司被独裁政权武器化，向澳大利亚传播虚假信息”。

;

;该报告还要求堪培拉建立“国家安全技术办公室”，以“映射现有的暴露情况” TikTok、微信和任何类似应用程序等高风险供应商”。

;

;调查和报告强调了堪培拉和澳大利亚人对中国政府利用社交媒体推进其政治利益的能力的具体担忧。

;

; p>;

;独立的澳中关系研究所等机构的调查显示，大多数澳大利亚人希望禁止微信和 TikTok，因为它们与中国有联系。

;

;但是格雷格·奥斯汀 (Greg Austin) 等专家，俄罗斯和中国问题的一位网络安全专家表示，虽然对外国通过此类应用程序进行干预的担忧至关重要，但调查报告存在缺陷，其中部分内容“歇斯底里”。

;

;“从某种意义上说，调查报告是一件重要的事情，但我认为，乍一看就很明显，它更多地针对中国，而不是其他进行政治干预的国家。它揭示了人们对世界上重要的事情缺乏深入的理解，”奥斯汀说，他也是悉尼科技大学的兼职教授和社交网络集团的联合创始人。

;

;“什么不是几乎所有[调查]文件都证明，所有权和秘密影响行动之间存在明显的联系。例如，如果研究微信，就可以找到中国秘密影响行动的证据，但也可以找到美国直接针对中国的秘密影响行动的证据。”

;

;奥斯汀表示，谁拥有微信并不重要。应用程序，因为情报机构可以利用任何社交媒体系统来施加影响。

;

;“澳大利亚对微信的禁令不会阻止俄罗斯、以色列和美国等其他国家在澳大利亚进行秘密影响行动......不能阻止中国在澳大利亚进行秘密影响行动。”

;

;微信告诉澳大利亚调查中国从未要求监视用户

;

;主持调查的主席、著名的对华鹰派澳大利亚参议员然而，詹姆斯·帕特森周二告诉参议院，社交媒体平台武器化的能力取决于其总部所在国的法律。

;

;调查委员会的其他参议员表示 - 另外报告中的评论——他们不支持针对特定平台，因为“他们没有采取任何措施保护澳大利亚人免受外国干涉”。

;

;“禁止 TikTok 或任何其他单一平台使用政府设备只不过是一场游戏绿党参议员 Sarah Hanson-Young 和 David Shoebridge 说：“这是数字打地鼠的行为，对保护澳大利亚人毫无帮助。”

;

;工党参议员 Jess Walsh 和 Raff Ciccone 表示，监管和透明度比具体目标更重要，任何新的禁令都应“听取各机构的建议”。

;

;该报告提到了两位学者提交的意见，他们表示，例如微信禁令将损害澳大利亚的民主，但没有提及提交的意见西方自由民主国家的社交媒体平台被认定侵犯用户隐私。

;

;上周，澳大利亚一家法院对 Facebook 所有者 Meta 处以 2000 万澳元的罚款，该公司出席了调查听证会，原因是通过以下方式收集用户数据：智能手机应用程序，但不透露其操作。据路透社报道，这笔罚款解决了 Meta 在澳大利亚的一系列法律问题，这些问题与 Meta 在 2016 年美国大选中使用数据分析公司 Cambridge Analytica 的全球丑闻有关。

;

;Meta 告诉《亚洲周刊》，它目前正在审查调查报告。

;港交所前老板联合创办的投资平台Micro Connect香港交易所李小加将于周四下午正式推出其澳门交易所，旨在帮助中国小型企业筹集资金。

;

;Micro Connect 澳门金融资产交易所 (MCEX) 正式推出恰逢该公司两周岁生日，一天前该公司宣布在 C 轮融资中筹集了 4.58 亿美元，使其估值达到 17 亿美元。 Micro Connect已通过三轮融资筹集了5.78亿美元。

;

;“强大的股东基础和新筹集的资金将支持Micro Connect加强MCEX的市场结构并开发全球最大的小微金融市场该公司表示。

;

;MCEX 不是传统交易所，因为它不交易股票或债券，而是一种称为每日收入义务 (DRO) 的新资产类别。机构投资者可以购买DRO单位，这些单位为中国的小微企业提供资金，以换取其日常收入的一部分。

;

;“微通的新交易所应该能够帮助内地的小企业获得资金因为他们通常不容易获得银行贷款，”证券交易商协会永久名誉会长陈伯林表示。

;

;“这也将有助于澳门通过更多的金融活动实现经济多元化。 ”

;

;在超额认购的C轮融资中，微连科技吸引了红杉资本、联想投资、Vectr Fintech和Dara Holdings的投资，这些公司也参与了之前的融资。总部位于爱丁堡的Baillie Gifford是最新一轮的新投资者。

;

;香港交易所前老板通过澳门将海外投资者与中国大陆的小企业联系起来

;

;来自欧洲、北美的其他投资者美国、中东和大中华区是长期投资管理公司、私募股权和风险基金、大学捐赠基金、互联网平台和消费零售集团。

;

;李现年 62 岁，与金融家加里 (Gary) 共同创立了 Micro Connect张先生于 2020 年 12 月离开香港交易所，于 2021 年 8 月成立。其目标是为无法获得银行贷款资格的小企业提供扩张资金。

;

;中国大陆此类企业的潜在群体包括 4000 万中小企业根据中央政府 2022 年的数据，该交易所已于 3 月份试运行，价值 8.9 亿元人民币（1.24 亿美元）的 DRO 可供交易平台会员，包括银行、保险公司、养老基金或其他集体投资计划。

;

;MCEX会员迄今已在中国大陆198个城市的9,000家商店投资了2.38亿美元，涉及行业包括食品、饮料、据其网站介绍，零售、文化和体育领域。

;

;香港虚拟银行平安壹账通将扩大对零售中小企业的贷款

;

;该交易平台是继南光之后在澳门推出的第二个交易平台（集团）于2018年8月成立了中华（澳门）金融资产交易所，以发行债券。

;

;这些进展是在北京于2019年12月宣布一系列政策通过建设金融服务业使澳门经济多元化之后发生的。这些政策之一是计划建立一个类似纳斯达克的证券交易所，以人民币计价，但尚未公布启动日期。

;

;陈表示，香港应该为主办MCEX等交易所扫清道路。

;

;“令人遗憾的是，这个新交易所不是在香港设立，而是在澳门设立，”他说。 “我们的监管机构可能需要审查法规，以使新平台更容易在香港设立并筹集资金。”

;克里斯托弗·诺兰的大片《奥本海默》即将在中国影迷中掀起热潮电影定于本月晚些时候在中国上映。

;

;7月25日，环球影业在微博（中国类似于Twitter的社交媒体平台）的官方账户宣布，该电影将于8月30日上映.

;

;电影于 7 月 20 日在香港首映，并于 7 月 21 日全球上映几天后，这个令导演庞大的内地影迷们高度期待的消息传来了。

;

;成千上万的人迎来了欢迎微博上发布了这一消息，有人评论道：“迟到总比不到好。”

;

;这一消息让一些人感到震惊，他们认为该片在内地上映“不可能”，因为该片在内地的评级为 R 级。一些人还担心其反共内容无法通过中国严格的政治审查规则。

;

;这部由希里安·墨菲 (Cillian Murphy) 主演的传记片《艾米丽·布朗特》和《马特·达蒙》聚焦于理论物理学家 J·罗伯特·奥本海默的一生，他领导了曼哈顿计划，研制出了第一批核武器，被称为“原子弹之父”。

;

;这部电影还讲述了二战后举行的听证会，听证会上奥本海默因过去的共产主义背景而受到指控。

;

;影响影评的新天地光影在他的博客中表示，这一消息意味着这部电影已经通过了审查测试，但补充说，“目前尚不清楚大陆版本是否会更改台词或字幕。”

;

;随着曼哈顿计划导致原子弹爆炸，大陆社交媒体对这部电影的期望也很高被投放到日本广岛和长崎，这可能导致日本无条件投降并结束对中国的侵略。

;

;至于裸体场景，一些社交媒体观察家推测大陆版本将复制印度和中东的做法，在性爱场景中为弗洛伦斯·普 (Florence Pugh) 饰演的赤裸上身的吉恩·塔特洛克 (Jean Tatlock) 添加一件 CGI 黑色连衣裙。

;

;“这样做比修剪整个场景更好”，一位在线观察者说道。

;

;另一位网友猜测，裸露场景将被剪掉，因此不会留下“敏感内容”，他指的是中国女演员范冰冰 2014 年电视剧《武则天传奇》中的著名例子，其中女性角色的乳沟被删除，只留下特写头像。

;

;网络上也重新燃起了对中国大陆电影分级制度的呼声。

;

;克里斯托弗·诺兰（Christopher Nolan）凭借热门科幻片《盗梦空间》和《星际穿越》，他在大陆建立了忠实的粉丝群，这两部影片均跻身豆瓣 250 部电影排行榜前 10 名——根据超过 1.7 亿条评分和中国电影用户留下的评论通过算法排名。最著名的收视网站。

;

;据福布斯报道，《星际穿越》在中国的票房收入为 1.22 亿美元，占 2014 年全球票房的 26%。

;

;一些大陆人曾前往《奥本海默》在内地上映后，香港仍将观看，以“看完整版，早点看”。

;

;而电影影响者则传出消息，香港多家电影院将独家放映35毫米电影

;

;香港百老汇院线本月还为内地影迷安排了一场特别的35毫米放映。

;< p>;尽管中国每年限制进口海外电影的数量，但内地电影观众还是充分利用了每年一度的北京和上海电影节，数百部经典和最新的外国电影在两个城市的影院放映。;

;另一部大片《芭比娃娃》于 7 月 21 日在内地上映，并立即获得好评如潮，尤其是来自女权主义者的好评，该片因两部电影的上映日期相似而引发了全球“巴本海默”现象。

;中国科学家估计，近期加拿大山火造成了10亿吨二氧化碳排放7 月 27 日，远远超过了加拿大人类活动造成的温室气体排放量。

;

;根据加拿大跨机构森林消防中心 (CIFFC) 的数据，今年加拿大火灾季节的烧毁面积是有记录以来最大的。据报道，截至 7 月底，今年迄今已有 129,800 平方公里（50,100 平方英里）的土地被烧毁，而 2022 年全年的烧毁面积为 14,700 平方公里。

;

;野火的排放量为根据加拿大政府环境与气候变化部门的数据，到 2021 年，加拿大人类活动产生的温室气体排放总量将增加近一倍。

;

;中国科学院 (CAS) 报告称，应用生态研究所 ( IAE）参与这项研究的科学家利用遥感技术，根据排放强度和燃烧面积来评估快速排放。

;

;负责这项研究的 IAE 森林火灾专家刘志华表示，这些火灾“对全球气候变暖有着不可否认的影响”。

;

;科学家还估计，火灾排放的一氧化二氮和甲烷的温室效应相当于1.1亿吨二氧化碳。随着永久冻土层的燃烧，可能会释放出更多储存的甲烷。

;

;2022 年，政府机构加拿大自然资源部 (NRCan) 预测，到本世纪末，燃烧面积可能是近几十年来的两倍。今年燃烧的面积已经超过了预测。

;

;野火烟雾如何扰乱当地天气，并引发更极端的火灾

;

; Thu, 03 Aug 2023 08:20:03 +0800 China’s natural science fund supports new ‘chiplet’ tech research to advance semiconductor self-sufficiency amid threat of new US sanctionshttps://www.scmp.com/tech/policy/article/3229760/chinas-natural-science-fund-supports-new-chiplet-tech-research-advance-semiconductor-self?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.08.03 08:00;

;国家自然科学基金委员会 (NSFC)，国内主要资助来源基础研究和前沿探索，启动了一项新计划，资助数十个专注于“chiplet”技术的项目，这被视为该国在美国制裁下实现半导体自给自足的捷径。

;

;据一份报告称，隶属于科学技术部的国家自然科学基金委员会计划为多达 30 个研究项目提供高达 4600 万元人民币（640 万美元）的资助，这些项目将在三到四年内进行。 notice published on its website on Monday. It said applications will be accepted from September 1 through 7.

;

;Chiplets, pre-developed silicon dies that can be packaged into a more complex processor, have gained much interest on the mainland because they reduce design costs and may even offer a solution to extending Moore's Law, which refers to the doubling in the number of transistors on an integrated circuit (IC) every two years.

;

;The goal of the NSFC's latest programme is to “develop a research team with international influence to improve China's indigenous innovation capabilities” in the field of semiconductors, according to the foundation's notice.

;

;The programme aims to find “a new technology path” for China in semiconductors through breakthroughs in the assembly and integration of chiplets, with an eye to raising the performance of these devices by “one or two levels”, the NSFC said.

;

;It expects to fund research projects that include methods to dissect, combine and reuse chiplets, semiconductor design, three-dimensional chip processing techniques and the structure of high-performance ICs.

;

;The NSFC's new initiative underscores Beijing's resolve to push forward the country's semiconductor self-sufficiency efforts amid US-led trade sanctions, which have derailed the mainland's standing in global supply chains.

;

;The country's semiconductor development plans are expected to take another hit by the middle of this month, when US President Joe Biden reportedly plans to sign an executive order to limit critical US technology investments in China.

;

;'Solid innovation': China's Xi renews self-reliance call as US steps up tech war

;

;That executive order will reportedly focus on semiconductors, artificial intelligence and quantum computing. It will not affect any existing investments and will only prohibit certain transactions. Other deals will have to be disclosed to the US government.

;

;Washington's implementation of broad controls over China's ability to secure advanced ICs and semiconductor-manufacturing equipment have forced Beijing and mainland enterprises to sharpen their focus on the production of older-generation chips – a development that has US and European officials increasingly concerned.

;

;Established in 1986, the NSFC is responsible for directing, coordinating and making use of the national natural science fund to support basic research. The foundation increased its funding to 33 billion yuan last year, up 6.8 per cent over 2021.

;

;On the sidelines of the Two Sessions in March, Minister of Science and Technology Wang Zhigang said the country must “work on promoting a research environment that tolerates failure and encourages researchers to take more time”. That was because research “in basic areas often has unclear paths, uncertain methods and a relatively high failure rate”, according to a report by the South China Morning Post.

Drones, crawler robot at Hong Kong’s CLP Power cut inspection times from 12 to 1 dayhttps://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/society/article/3229764/faster-humans-drones-crawler-robot-hong-kongs-clp-power-cut-inspection-times-12-1-day?utm_source=rss_feed

;Hong Kong electricity provider CLP Power has said its five-drone fleet and crawler robot have reduced facility inspection times at its power plants, adding that the technology has also helped cut expenses.

;

;CLP Power engineers said the equipment had cut inspection times from 12 to one or two days in some instances and resulted in more flexible arrangements for carrying out checks.

;

;Robots were capable of examining the facilities in greater detail than humans, and could help reduce safety hazards for workers operating in confined areas, they added.

;

;The company has two cage drones for internal checks and three outdoor drones for external checks.

;

;“Now we can conduct inspections swiftly and we only need to apply scaffolding to specific locations where defects have been identified by drones,” Grace Wong Chung-yan, a CLP engineer, said on Tuesday. “This has made the inspection and repair work more efficient.”

;

;Drones had helped cut the inspection time for 80-metre-tall boilers from 12 to one or two days, while it only took two days instead of up to seven to check a 1.4km culvert using a crawler robot, which was introduced in 2021.

;

;Who needs a teacher? I've got ChatGPT! Hong Kong educationists worry about future

;

;Wong said the drones could create three-dimensional models of the inspected facilities and comparing different versions of the mock-ups could help identify discrepancies easily.

;

;“Facilities at power plants are huge. Finding defects is like finding a needle at sea. Some are in hidden places or dead corners, and they can easily be missed by humans,” she said.

;

;“The drones are small and flexible. They can go to places that are unreachable by humans.”

;

;Hong Kong's fire services use artificial intelligence to help find stranded hikers

;

;Cage drones, outdoor drones and the crawler robot are currently being used at two of CLP's power plants – Castle Peak Power Station and Black Point Power Station, both in Tuen Mun, while the firm deploys only outdoor drones at Penny's Bay Power Station on Lantau Island for external inspections.

;

;The company used outdoor drones to examine its external facilities back in 2016, but engineers found they did not perform well in confined spaces, such as turbine halls and boilers, as the technology relied on GPS systems for location tracking, but the signals could not penetrate the thick walls.

;

;CLP then introduced the cage drones for internal facility inspections in 2019. The technology uses the Light Detection and Ranging (LiDAR) system and sensors for positioning, which are not subject to GPS signals. Carbon fibre cages surround the drones to help avoid collisions.

;

;“Drones can keep an eye on the facilities, but cleaning and repairs are still done by humans,” Wong said.

;

;According to Ng Ki-on, CLP's director of generation engineering, the company's use of technology had matured recently. He added that the company was trying to develop equipment to carry out simple maintenance work.

;

;“We'll try to develop some drones which can do maintenance work. But that will not be easy,” he said.

;

;The drones have helped reduce inspection expenses, according to the company.

;

;“A cage drone costs hundreds of thousands of Hong Kong dollars and can be used multiple times, but setting up full-scale scaffoldings can cost HK$2-3 million every time,” Ng said.

;

;CLP has been using the crawler robot to check its underground culverts since 2021, which has reduced inspection times by more than a half.

;

;“Human inspectors had to carry equipment weighing more than 10kg to walk down the culverts. And some parts of the culverts are just 1.8 metres tall, and an adult man would have to bend down with such heavy weight to pass through them, which is very demanding on the body,” said Selena Yang Huimin, a senior engineer at CLP.

;

;“With footage filmed by the robot, we can formulate a more accurate maintenance strategy, and avoid having humans working in risky and confined spaces,” she added.

; Thu, 03 Aug 2023 08:20:03 +0800 Two airlines, two apologies: why Cathay’s worked but United’s failedhttps://www.scmp.com/comment/opinion/article/3229599/two-airlines-two-apologies-why-cathays-worked-uniteds-failed?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.08.03 08:15;
;;

;Both Cathay Pacific Airways and United Airlines recently issued apologies. Public reception suggests Cathay's was more effective.

;

;Apologies can have different meanings depending on how much they acknowledge that an injury has been inflicted and that it was wrong. Victims' psychological needs (restoration of dignity, assurance of shared values and safety, and seeing the perpetrator suffer) are usually more greatly satisfied when both aspects are more prominently displayed.

;

;Cathay Pacific's offence was revealed by a recording of flight attendants mocking a Mandarin-speaking passenger for confusing the words “carpet” and “blanket”. United Airlines' offence was documented by a photo of its CEO Scott Kirby boarding a private jet while more than 150,000 United passengers were stranded by cancelled flights due to weather disruptions. Both events were publicised on social media and publicly condemned.

;

;Quality apologies usually consist of four elements. First, acknowledge the harm without vagueness, minimising, conditions or using the passive voice. Second, express remorse and self-condemnation. Third, explain (making sure it is not a justification). And fourth, offer reparations.

;

;Cathay affirmed that its flight attendants' conduct was wrong and apologised repeatedly – a culturally significant demonstration of deep remorse. The airline issued four apologies in three days, with CEO Ronald Lam apologising personally multiple times.

;

;The apology began with an expression of deep concern, another gesture communicating remorse. Reparations were included in the original apology in that the three crew members were suspended; the next day, Lam said they had been fired.

;

;Cathay's commitment to restitution included a promise to rectify root issues with a review of its service processes, personnel training and language skills.

;

;Cathay met the victim's psychological needs of restoration of dignity by deferring to mainland Chinese culture in how it delivered its apologies. It published the apology on Weibo in simplified Chinese and Lam has also apologised in Mandarin.

;

;Cathay satiated public demand by having its highest-ranking representative publicly agree it had acted badly and offer restitution through harshly punishing the offenders and systemically reviewing and correcting its policies and practices.

;

;In contrast, Kirby's apology was issued in a statement: “Taking a private jet was the wrong decision because it was insensitive to our customers who were waiting to get home. I sincerely apologise to our customers and our team members”.

;

;Kirby commended the hard work of United's employees and promised to show more respect for employees and customers. But he used mild negatives such as “wrong decision”, “insensitive” and “distraction”. United attempted to assure the public of better behaviour but provided only a vague promise of respect.

;

;It also failed to promise corrective action or specific forbearance. Kirby attempted to meet United employees' and passengers' needs of dignity restoration by praising their hard work and patience. The airline also offered restitution in the form of air miles.

;

;But Kirby did not properly address the trigger – the disparity between his lavish lifestyle and the plight of United employees and passengers – and so failed to dispel the disrespect felt. One passenger tweeted a screenshot of Kirby's US$10 million annual salary in response to his apology.

;

;Kirby's apology also failed to meet the need for shared values. His acknowledgement of wrongful behaviour was lukewarm, giving United employees and passengers the impression of placation.

;

;Cathay on the right path to repairing its battered reputation

;

;In short, it seemed an empty apology. The most noticeable difference between the Cathay and United incidents is that Kirby appeared to face no consequences. He could have shown remorse by donating to a charitable fund in honour of affected United passengers and employees, or dedicating a pay cut to United employees.

;

;Admittedly, there is a difference between endemic discrimination and a public relations misstep. The moral repugnancy of ridiculing a passenger based on ethnicity and language skills can hardly be compared with taking a private chartered flight, a practice not unique to United's CEO.

;

;The stranded United passengers were tired, harangued and inconvenienced, but they were not disrespected or denigrated. Yet, strikingly, Cathay's apology is generally seen as more successful.

;

;Fundamentally, an effective apology must acknowledge and agree that harm was done. Talk is cheap, so such sentiments must be accompanied by offers of restitution. Cathay's apology seemed more authentic because it avoided passive language, assured action and connected with the victim.

;K-pop lovers in Indonesia have panned presidential hopeful Ganjar Pranowo for proposing to host a concert in Central Java, seemingly aimed at wooing young voters ahead of next year's general election.

;

;Ganjar recently said his campaigner and Surakarta Mayor Gibran Rakabuming Raka were eyeing inviting K-pop stars to the city, and he had no idea who to tap on.

;

;The presidential candidate of the Democratic Party of Struggle (PDI-P), which includes Indonesian president and Gibran's father Joko Widodo, also sought suggestions from social media users.

;

;Is there a rift between Jokowi, Megawati in battle of Indonesia's kingmakers?

;

;While some recommended bands like K-pop heavyweight BTS and the new boy group Xodiac, others questioned Ganjar's intention behind using a music show to connect with the electorate, saying he needs to focus on policies promoting work-life balance and freedom of expression.

;

;“Soliciting ideas from K-pop fans? There's still a lot of work to do. It's not the time to relax and watch entertainment,” a user responded to the Central Java governor on X, formerly known as Twitter.

;

;K-pop fans also accused Ganjar of capitalising on the genre to score political mileage and lacking “quality ideas”, suggesting he give local singers a chance to showcase their work.

;

;“Please talk about what Indonesia will be like in the future, sir. How are you going to deal with traffic jams?” asked a user.

;

;Netizens also said K-pop idols in South Korea typically stayed clear of politics during elections, and Ganjar should not use them as a “political tool” in his campaigns.

;

;Ganjar backed down as opposition to his plan grew, insisting it had “nothing to do with politics” and was initiated as a way to boost the local economy and tourism business.

;

;“But, if our intention has displeased some people, then that's OK too,” he said in a post on X.

;

;Some K-pop devotees were not convinced with that explanation, saying his intention was to turn the event into votes and that is exactly why they do not support him.

;

;Wrote a user: “You're a political person, you're running for the president's office and you can't get away from what's called a political agenda.”

;

;Mayor Gibran had said he planned to hold the concert in September to mark the 50th year anniversary of Indonesia's diplomatic relationship with South Korea, The Jakarta Post reported.

;

;It was not immediately clear if the Surakarta show would take place following the outcry.

;

;

;During the 2014 presidential contest, Widodo confessed he was a heavy metal fan and declared his love for Metallica and Napalm Death.

;

;“Incredibly, ladies and gentlemen, the new president of Indonesia is a metalhead and a Lamb of God fan,” said Randy Blythe, singer of the American band Lamb of God, after Widodo won the election.
